headline.main: NASA CHIEF SAYS FIFTH SPACE SHUTTLE IS NEEDED

results.snippet: THE head of the space agency said yesterday that NASA needed a fifth space shuttle to meet increased launching demands in the early 1990's, calling construction of a fifth spacecraft ''an absolute necessity.''   Dr. James C. Fletcher, head of the...
results.lead_paragraph: THE head of the space agency said yesterday that NASA needed a fifth space shuttle to meet increased launching demands in the early 1990's, calling construction of a fifth spacecraft ''an absolute necessity.'' Dr. James C. Fletcher, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, said in an interview that a fleet of four orbiters would be unable to carry all the military, scientific, and space station payloads scheduled for launching in the early 1990's. ''With the space station on top of everything else, a fifth orbiter is an absolute necessity,'' he said. The decision to build a fifth space shuttle would have to be made in the next year or two, he added.

headline.main: HOUSE ACTS TO HOLD SPACE STATION

results.snippet: The House voted today to prohibit the space agency from proceeding with development of the $8 billion space station until the agency makes certain design changes on the project.   The provision was adopted by a voice vote as an amendment to the $54...
results.lead_paragraph: The House voted today to prohibit the space agency from proceeding with development of the $8 billion space station until the agency makes certain design changes on the project. The provision was adopted by a voice vote as an amendment to the $54 billion appropriation bill to operate the Department of Housing and Urban Development and 17 other Federal agencies in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1. The overall bill was approved by a vote of 295 to 46.

results.snippet: Having chided Senator Jake Garn for soliciting a ride aboard the space shuttle while overseeing NASA's budget, we are happy now to salute his decency and courage in donating a kidney to his daughter Susan.   A diabetic from childhood, she suffered...
results.lead_paragraph: Having chided Senator Jake Garn for soliciting a ride aboard the space shuttle while overseeing NASA's budget, we are happy now to salute his decency and courage in donating a kidney to his daughter Susan. A diabetic from childhood, she suffered kidney failure for which a transplant was the only remedy. Mr. Garn stepped ahead of two of his sons, who also would have been compatible donors to provide it.

headline.main: LAVI FIGHTER: A GRUMMAN-ISRAEL PARTNERSHIP WOULD BE GOOD FOR L.I.

results.snippet: THE Grumman Corporation has a historic opportunity to contribute to Israel's strength and America's security while at the same time bringing more jobs to Long Island and strengthening its position in the aerospace industry.   The key to this...

byline.original: By Lawrence J. Epstein; This article was written by Lawrence J. Epstein, Steve Israel and Lewis B. Meltzer, officials of the Suffolk Political Action Committee, a pro-Israel group based in Suffolk County

results.lead_paragraph: THE Grumman Corporation has a historic opportunity to contribute to Israel's strength and America's security while at the same time bringing more jobs to Long Island and strengthening its position in the aerospace industry. The key to this opportunity is to agree to ''co-produce'' the Lavi fighter aircraft with Israel. Recent reports indicate that Israel has approached Grumman as a potential partner in the development of the Lavi and that Grumman is considering this offer. Long Island stands a great deal to gain in a Grumman-Israel partnership.

headline.main: NASA HAD SOLUTION TO KEY FLAW IN ROCKET WHEN SHUTTLE EXPLODED

results.snippet: The key solution proposed by the space agency to the problem that caused the Challenger explosion was devised years before the disaster and was being systematically applied to the entire space shuttle fleet, interviews, documents and testimony...
results.lead_paragraph: The key solution proposed by the space agency to the problem that caused the Challenger explosion was devised years before the disaster and was being systematically applied to the entire space shuttle fleet, interviews, documents and testimony show. The record shows longstanding worry about seals on the shuttle and application of an innovative remedy to generations of booster rockets. It also shows why the solution was unavailable for the Challenger flight of Jan. 28, in which a leaky booster seal touched off an explosion that destroyed the craft and killed its seven astronauts. To critics, this new history suggests duplicity on the part of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration: While publicly declaring the shuttle safe to fly, these critics say, NASA officials knew the flaw was grave and had quietly embarked on a major program to fix it. Denial From NASA NASA officials vigorously deny this charge, insisting they were unaware of the seriousness of the flaw and were simply trying to increase the booster's margin of safety.

headline.main: 7 ASTRONAUTS' SURVIVORS OPEN $1 MILLION FOUNDATION DRIVE

results.snippet: The surviving families of the astronauts who died aboard the space shuttle Challenger said Monday that they had begun a campaign to raise $1 million to establish programs in space sciences education and training for teachers and students.   The...

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

results.lead_paragraph: The surviving families of the astronauts who died aboard the space shuttle Challenger said Monday that they had begun a campaign to raise $1 million to establish programs in space sciences education and training for teachers and students. The Challenger Foundation, the only fund-raising effort actively supported by the families of all seven astronauts, will use the funds to establish an education center that they hope to affiliate with the Smithsonian Institution here, said June Scobee, widow of Francis R. Scobee, commander of the shuttle's last mission.

results.snippet: The husband of the teacher-astronaut Christa C. McAuliffe was named a state university trustee today, replacing the controversial nomination of Max Hugel, a race track owner. Gov. John H. Sununu's selection of Steven McAuliffe, a lawyer, was...
results.lead_paragraph: The husband of the teacher-astronaut Christa C. McAuliffe was named a state university trustee today, replacing the controversial nomination of Max Hugel, a race track owner. Gov. John H. Sununu's selection of Steven McAuliffe, a lawyer, was unanimously approved by the Executive Council.

results.snippet: Since the nation's first manned space flight in 1961, engineers who design spacecraft have argued about margins of safety, weighing cost and time against risk to human life. But it was always a quiet debate, behind closed doors, and almost never...
results.lead_paragraph: Since the nation's first manned space flight in 1961, engineers who design spacecraft have argued about margins of safety, weighing cost and time against risk to human life. But it was always a quiet debate, behind closed doors, and almost never framed in life-or-death terms. No longer. When the Challenger disintegrated in the clear Florida skies eight months ago today, it triggered changes the National Aeronautics and Space Administration never thought possible. The most immediate, one NASA official said with some bitterness the other day, is ''a loss of autonomy'' - with astronauts, Congress, some of the nation's leading scientists, the press and the public all questioning the agency's safety judgments.

headline.main: SILENCE ABOUT SHUTTLE FLAW ATTRIBUTED TO PITFALLS OF PRIDE

results.snippet: PRIDE, self-deception and institutional loyalty were some of the factors that aerospace experts say kept the space agency from sounding alarm bells years ago when it discovered the flaw that would cause the Challenger disaster and embarked on...
results.lead_paragraph: PRIDE, self-deception and institutional loyalty were some of the factors that aerospace experts say kept the space agency from sounding alarm bells years ago when it discovered the flaw that would cause the Challenger disaster and embarked on sweeping efforts to fix it. Former space agency officials and other outside experts, reacting to recent reports of the repair program, said such factors prompted the space agency to minimize the importance of the repairs and to carry them out slowly. The hubris was contagious, these experts add: Journalists too often limited their space agency coverage to the adventure of flight; members of Congress were cheerleaders instead of overseers, and the White House helped create an atmosphere in which other issues took a back seat to making the space shuttle pay for itself by carrying commercial payloads aloft. ''Blame should be equally distributed,'' said Alex Roland, who was a historian with the National Aeronautics and Space Administration from 1973 to 1981. ''Everybody wanted to believe NASA was squeaky clean.''
